subjectDescription: Discover a full suite of online business courses that will allow you to make better business decisions and succeed in today's competitive business world. Our courses provide a rich learning experience that will allow you to develop critical business skills in areas such as business... Read more...
title: Diploma in Business Process Management
headline: Learn more about business process management, systems analysis and design, and their implementation with this course.
description: This free online Diploma in Business Process Management course will explain business intelligence and knowledge management systems, systems analysis, systems design, and systems implementation. Major advances in technology have resulted in the widespread implementation of information system into businesses and organizations. With this course, you will learn how to design, test, and implement information systems for a business process.
courseDescription:
This course begins by giving you an introduction to business process and information systems. You will learn that an information system serves two important functions within an organization. You will study the elements in the study of information system and the components of a business process. You will study the difference between data and information as well as the qualities of information. You will then learn how to read data flow diagrams, system flowcharts, and entity-relationship diagrams.

You will then learn to identify some of the information tools designed to help decision-makers. Decision making is the process of making choices and is the central activity of all management. The nature of the information required by managers differs depending on the management level. With this course, you will learn about the function of Neural Network, the three steps in decision making, and the differences between structured and unstructured decisions.

The management of processes and data are critical to the overall success of a business. Upon the completion of this course, you will gain an understanding of systems development life cycle, business process engineering, and groupware system. In addition, you will be able to understand what a system survey is and learn the different steps involved in the process of evaluating the vendor proposal. Check out this course and start your learning journey now!

Start Course Now
certificateDetail:
All Alison courses are free to enrol study and complete. To successfully complete this course and become an Alison Graduate, you need to achieve 80% or higher in each course assessment. Once you have completed this course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison is:
  • Ideal for sharing with potential employers
  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital : a downloadable in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • : a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked , posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed : a physical version of your officially branded and security marked in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.

All are available to purchase through the Alison Shop. For more information on purchasing Alison , please visit our FAQs. If you decide not to purchase your Alison , you can still demonstrate your achievement by sharing your Learner Record or Learner Achievement Verification, both of which are accessible from your Dashboard. For more details on our pricing, please visit our Pricing Page

• After completing this module you will be able to:
    • Identify what is an information system.
    • List and explain the elements in the study of information systems.
    • Describe the terms “system” and “subsystem”.
  • Systems and Subsystems
  • A system is a set of interdependent elements that together accomplish specific objectives. 

    A system must have:
    • organization
    • interrelationships
    • integration
    • central objectives

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Each part of a system is known as a subsystem. Within limits, any subsystem can be further divided into its component parts or subsystems.

  • Elements in the Study of Information Systems
  • Hardware and Software:
  • The ability to plan and manage business operations depends partly on knowledge of the hardware and software available. It goes without saying that technological developments have a profound effect on information systems. Examples of such are: enterprise systems, e-business, databases, and business intelligence systems.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Hardware and software technology provides the foundation on which Information System and business operations rest.
  • Databases:
  • Important to a complete understanding of Information System are databases, both internal and external to the company; the quantity and type of data available in these databases; and methods of retrieving those data.

    To perform analysis or to prepare information for management decision making, a business professional must be able to access and use data from internal and external databases.

  • The key points from this module are:
    • A system is a set of interdependent elements that together accomplish specific objectives. 
    • A system must have organization, interrelationships, integration, and central objectives.
    • Each part of a system is known as a subsystem. Within limits, any subsystem can be further divided into its component parts or subsystems.
    • The ability to plan and manage business operations depends partly on knowledge of the hardware and software available. 
    • Important to a complete understanding of Information Systems are databases, both internal and external to the company; the quantity and type of data available in these databases; and methods of retrieving those data.
    • To design reports generated by an information system, the business professional must know what outputs are required or desirable.
    • A user might prepare a report on an occasional basis using powerful report-generating tools or a database query language.
    • Traditionally, internal auditors and Information Systems professionals have been charged with controlling business processes. However, this responsibility has expanded to others because of the difficulty of controlling modern, complex business processes.
    • A business process is a set of business events that together enable the creation and delivery of an organization’s products or services to its customers.
    • Organizations engage in activities or operations, such as hiring employees, purchasing inventory, and collecting cash from customers. An Information System operates in concert with these business operations.

  • After completing this module you will be able to:
    • Identify what is a business process and describe its components.
    • Describe the “Business Process” model.
    • Describe the system output flow and users.
  • Introduction
  • A business process has three component processes that work together to support its logical activities. The Information System supports all three processes in that it frequently embodies many of the policies and procedures that help define each process. 

    These processes work together to accomplish the objectives of the business process and therefore thee organisation.

    The information process is that portion of the overall Information System relate to a particular business process.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • The information process plays a critical role in the way all three processes work together.

  • Output Flow and Users
  • Introduction
    In the diagram attached, the top three layers represent the management process. The bottom layer represents the organization’s operations processes. The information process supports all layers through horizontal and vertical information flows. 

    By studying these flows more closely; we can improve our understanding of the Information System and its relationships with the operations and the management processes.

  • The Key points form this module are:
    • A business process has three component processes that work together to support its logical activities. 
    • The Information System supports all three processes in that it frequently embodies many of the policies and procedures that help define each process.
    • The information process is that portion of the overall IS related to a particular business process. The information process plays a critical role in the way all three processes work together.
    • An operations process is a human-made system consisting of the people, equipment, organization, policies, and procedure whose objective is to accomplish the work of the organization.
    • The management process is a human-made system consisting of the people, authority, organization, policies, and procedures whose objective is to plan and control the operations of the organization.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

    • An operations process is a human-made system consisting of the people, equipment, organization, policies, and procedure whose objective is to accomplish the work of the organization.
    • The management process is a human-made system consisting of the people, authority, organization, policies, and procedures whose objective is to plan and control the operations of the organization.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • After completing this module you will be able to:  
    • Identify the difference between data and information.
    • List and explain the qualities of information.
  • Management Uses of Information
  • An Information System serves two important functions within an organization. 

    First, the Information System mirrors and monitors actions in the operations process by processing, recording, and reporting business events.

    The second major function of the Information System: to support managerial activities in the management process, including management decision making.
  • Managers need to know if enough inventory is being produced each day to meet expected demand.

    Managers’ second use of information is to help them achieve satisfactory results for all of their stakeholders. 

    Finally, managers use the information system to recognize and adapt in a timely manner to trends in the organization’s environment.

  • Costs and Benefits of Information
  • We often hear people say that before an action is undertaken, the estimated benefits of that action should exceed the estimated costs. This is a basic expectation.

    In business, we make an assumption that there is a cost associated with each improvement in the quality of information.

    Many companies use perpetual inventory balances for most of the year, or estimate their inventory balances based on sales or past years’ levels.

  • The key points from this module:
    • An Information System serves two important functions within an organization. 
    • First, the Information System mirrors and monitors actions in the operations process by processing, recording, and reporting business events.
    • The second major function of the Information Systems is to support managerial activities in the management process, including management decision making.
    • Managers need to know if enough inventory is being produced each day to meet expected demand. 
    • Managers’ second use of information is to help them achieve satisfactory results for all of their stakeholders.
    • Finally, managers use the information system to recognize and adapt in a timely manner to trends in the organization’s environment.
    • Information is data presented in a form that is useful in a decision-making activity. 
    • Data are facts or figures in raw form. Data represent the measurements or observations of objects and events.
    • The most basic function of an Information System, then, is to transform data into information that is useful in decision making.

    • Costs and Benefits of Information
      In business, we make an assumption that there is a cost associated with each improvement in the quality of information. In practice, the benefits and sometimes the costs of information are often hard to measure.
      In business, we make an assumption that there is a cost associated with each improvement in the quality of information. In practice, the benefits and sometimes the costs of information are often hard to measure.
      Customer ID

    • Conflicts Among Information Qualities
      It is virtually impossible to achieve a maximum level for all of the qualities of information simultaneously. In fact, for some qualities, an increased level of one requires a reduced level of another.
      It is virtually impossible to achieve a maximum level for all of the qualities of information simultaneously. In fact, for some qualities, an increased level of one requires a reduced level of another.
      Customer ID
      Customer Name
    • Prioritizing Information Qualities
      - In cases where there are conflicts between qualities of information, defining a hierarchy establishes the relative importance of each quality.
      - Maximizing one objective, rather than obtaining the highest possible levels for individual subordinate values, is a strategic choice.
      - Customers expect quality service, accurate and timely delivery of orders, and a well-run organization behind the flashy Web site.

  • A data flow diagram (DFD) is a graphical representation of a system. 

    A DFD depicts a system’s components, the data flows among the components, and the sources, destinations, and storage of data.

    Figure 1 shows the four symbols used in a DFD.

  • A data flow diagram (DFD) is a graphical representation of a system. 

    A DFD depicts a system’s components, the data flows among the components, and the sources, destinations, and storage of data.

    Figure 1 shows the four symbols used in a DFD.

  • Logical Data Flow Diagrams
  • A logical data flow diagram is a graphical representation of a system showing the system’s processes and the flows of data into and out of the processes. 

    We use logical DFD's to document information systems because we can represent the logical nature of a system-what tasks the system is doing- without having to specify how, where, or by whom the tasks are accomplished. 

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • What a system is doing will change less over time than how it is doing it.

    The advantage of a logical DFD (versus a physical DFD) is that we can concentrate on the functions that a system performs. 

    See, for example, Figure 4 in the Resources document, where the labels on the data flows describe the nature of the data, rather than how the data are transmitted.

    Is the “Payment” in the form of a check, cash, credit card, or debit card? We don’t know. Is “Sales data” a book, card, or records stored on a computer? Again, we don’t know.  
  • Logical Data Flow Diagrams

    We use logical DFD's to document information systems because we can represent the logical nature of a system-what tasks the system is doing- without having to specify how, where, or by whom the tasks are accomplished.

    Is the “Payment” in the form of a check, cash, credit card, or debit card? We don’t know. Is “Sales data” a book, card, or records stored on a computer? Again, we don’t know.  
  • Logical Data Flow Diagrams
  • A logical data flow diagram is a graphical representation of a system showing the system’s processes and the flows of data into and out of the processes. 

    We use logical DFD's to document information systems because we can represent the logical nature of a system-what tasks the system is doing- without having to specify how, where, or by whom the tasks are accomplished. 

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • What a system is doing will change less over time than how it is doing it.

    The advantage of a logical DFD (versus a physical DFD) is that we can concentrate on the functions that a system performs. 

    See, for example, Figure 4 in the Resources document, where the labels on the data flows describe the nature of the data, rather than how the data are transmitted.

    Is the “Payment” in the form of a check, cash, credit card, or debit card? We don’t know. Is “Sales data” a book, card, or records stored on a computer? Again, we don’t know.  
  • Logical Data Flow Diagrams
  • A logical data flow diagram is a graphical representation of a system showing the system’s processes and the flows of data into and out of the processes. 

    We use logical DFD's to document information systems because we can represent the logical nature of a system-what tasks the system is doing- without having to specify how, where, or by whom the tasks are accomplished. 

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • What a system is doing will change less over time than how it is doing it.

    The advantage of a logical DFD (versus a physical DFD) is that we can concentrate on the functions that a system performs. 

    See, for example, Figure 4 in the Resources document, where the labels on the data flows describe the nature of the data, rather than how the data are transmitted.

    Is the “Payment” in the form of a check, cash, credit card, or debit card? We don’t know. Is “Sales data” a book, card, or records stored on a computer? Again, we don’t know.  
  • Logical Data Flow Diagrams
  • A logical data flow diagram is a graphical representation of a system showing the system’s processes and the flows of data into and out of the processes. 

    We use logical DFD's to document information systems because we can represent the logical nature of a system-what tasks the system is doing- without having to specify how, where, or by whom the tasks are accomplished. 

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • What a system is doing will change less over time than how it is doing it.

    The advantage of a logical DFD (versus a physical DFD) is that we can concentrate on the functions that a system performs. 

    See, for example, Figure 4 in the Resources document, where the labels on the data flows describe the nature of the data, rather than how the data are transmitted.

    Is the “Payment” in the form of a check, cash, credit card, or debit card? We don’t know. Is “Sales data” a book, card, or records stored on a computer? Again, we don’t know.  
  • The key points from this module are:
  • A data flow diagram (DFD) is a graphical representation of a system.  A DFD depicts a system’s components, the data flows among the components, and the sources, destinations, and storage of data.

    A context diagram is a top-level or least-detailed diagram of an information system. The diagram describes data flows into and out of the system and into and out of external entities.

    A physical data flow diagram is a graphical representation of a system showing the system’s internal and external entities, and the flows of data into and out of these entities.

    A logical data flow diagram is a graphical representation of a system showing the system’s processes and the flows of data into and out of the processes. 

    The advantage of a logical DFD (versus a physical DFD) is that we can concentrate on the functions that a system performs. 

    When two DFD's have equivalent external data flows, we say that the DFD's are balanced. Only balanced sets of DFD's (that is, a context diagram, a logical DFD, and a physical DFD) are correct.

    The successive subdividing, or “exploding,” of logical DFD's is called top-down partitioning and, when properly performed, leads to a set of balanced DFD's.

  • Common Systems Flowcharting Routines

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Figures 7.1 - 7.7 contains routines often found on systems flowcharts. Figure 7.1, depicts a typical two-step data entry process which might be described as follows:

    The data entry clerk keys a sales input document while online. The computer accesses data in data store 1 and in data store 2 to edit/validate the input. The computer displays the input, including any errors. 

    The clerk compares the input document to the display, keys in corrections as necessary, and accepts the input. The computer updates the table in data store 2 and notifies the clerk that the input has been recorded.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • System Flowcharting Guidelines
  • Guideline 1:
    Divide the flowchart into columns; one column for each internal entity and one for each external entity. 

    Label each column.

    In Figure 7.7 in the Resources document, Scanning Clerk, Computer and Data Entry Clerk are all entities involved in the routine. So each get their own column.

  • After completing this module you will be able to:  
    • Identify what is an Entity-Relationship Diagram.
    • Explain the different relationships among entities.
  • Entity-Relationship Diagrams
  • As a professional you will likely be performing one or more of four functions. You might be:
    1. A business process owner.
    2. A designer of an Information System.
    3. An Information System user.
    4. An evaluator of an Information System. 
  • To effectively perform these roles, you must be aware of the procedures used to develop and install an Information System. 

    Systems development procedures include two concurrent and often inseparable processes: the development of the system procedures and the design of the database. 

    DFD's often portray system procedures, and entity-relationship diagrams often depict specifications for the database.

    A data model depicts user requirements for data in the database. The model is expressed as a structure of entities and relationships among those entities. 
  • Entity-Relationship Diagrams

  • As a professional you will likely be performing one or more of four functions. You might be:

  • To effectively perform these roles, you must be aware of the procedures used to develop and install an Information System. 

    Systems development procedures include two concurrent and often inseparable processes: the development of the system procedures and the design of the database. 

    DFD's often portray system procedures, and entity-relationship diagrams often depict specifications for the database.

    A data model depicts user requirements for data in the database. The model is expressed as a structure of entities and relationships among those entities. 
  • The key points from this module are:
  • An entity-relationship diagram (also called an E-R diagram) reflects the system’s key entities and the relationships among those entities and is commonly used to represent a data model.

    The rectangles are called “entities” and the diamonds are called “relationships.” 

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • The first of three relationship categories, is called “one-to-N,’’ and the notation is 1:N (or “N-to-one” and noted as N:1). 

    The second relationship category is called “M-to-N,” and the notation is M:N. 

    There is a third relationship category, called “one-to-one,” and it uses the notation 1:1.
  • After completing this module you will be able to:
    • Identify some of the information tools designed to help decision makers.
    • Describe the function of Neural Networks.
    • Describe the four levels of expertise that can be applied to unstructured decisions.
    • Describe the process known as “Decision Making”.
    • List the three steps in decision making.
    • Explain the differences between structured and unstructured decisions.
  • Management Decision Making
  • Decision making is the process of making choices. It is the central activity of all management.

    Managers make decisions or choices, such as what products to sell, in which markets to sell those products, what organizational structure to use, and how to direct and motivate employees.

    There are three steps in decision making:  

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

    1. Intelligence: Searching the environment for conditions calling for a decision.
    2. Design: Inventing, developing, and analyzing possible courses of action.
    3. Choice: Selecting a course of action.
  • The nature of the information required by managers varies by management level. 
  • Strategic level managers require information that allows them to assess the environment and to project future events and conditions.

    Tactical management requires information that is focused on relevant operational units. 

    Operational management needs information that is narrower in scope, more detailed, more accurate, and that comes largely from within the organization. The kind of information required to make a decision is also heavily influenced by the decision’s structure or lack thereof.

  • Information Tools
  • The Information System supporting a firm’s business processes focuses on information requirements that can be identified in advance: 

    Information for well-structured decision situations in which the typical information requirements can be anticipated.

    However, providing information to help managers make decisions is a rather daunting task.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • This section discusses some of the information tools designed to help decision makers:
    • Business Intelligence (BI) systems.
    • Online Analytical Processing systems (OLAP).
    • Group Support Systems (GSS).
    • Expert Systems.
    • and Intelligent Agents.
  • Information Tools

  • Artificial Intelligence
  • Many decision-making situations require a high level of expertise in a deep or complicated problem area.

    Artificial Intelligence (AI) facilitates the capture of expertise in many ways. In this section, we discuss three AI techniques, expert systems, neural networks and intelligent agents.
  • Expert systems (ES), may help decision makers overcome many of the roadblocks. Expert systems may be appropriate where:

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

    • Decisions are extremely complex.
    • Consistency of decision making is desirable.
    • The decision maker wishes to optimize the decision. That is, the decision maker wants to minimize time spent making the decision while maximizing the quality of the decision.
    • There is an expert decision maker, and his or her knowledge can be efficiently captured and effectively modelled via computer software.
  • Artificial Intelligence

    • Decisions are extremely complex.
    • Consistency of decision making is desirable.
    • The decision maker wishes to optimize the decision. That is, the decision maker wants to minimize time spent making the decision while maximizing the quality of the decision.
    • There is an expert decision maker, and his or her knowledge can be efficiently captured and effectively modelled via computer software.
  • The key points from this module are:
  • Decision making is the process of making choices. It is the central activity of all management. The nature of the information required by managers varies by management level. 

    There are three steps in decision making:
    1. Intelligence: Searching the environment for conditions calling for a decision.
    2. Design: Inventing, developing, and analyzing possible courses of action.
    3. Choice: Selecting a course of action.
  • Strategic level managers require information that allows them to assess the environment and to project future events and conditions. 

    Tactical management requires information that is focused on relevant operational units. 

    Operational management needs information that is narrower in scope, more detailed, more accurate, and that comes largely from within the organization.

    Structure is the degree of repetition and routine in the decision. We can use the degree of structure inherent in each decision-making step to categorize the decisions as structured or unstructured.

    We define structured decisions as those for which all three decision phases are relatively routine or repetitive. Thus, we define unstructured decisions as those for which all three decision phases are not routine and/or repetitive.
  • The key points from this module are:
  • Decision making is the process of making choices. It is the central activity of all management. The nature of the information required by managers varies by management level. 

    There are three steps in decision making:
    1. Intelligence: Searching the environment for conditions calling for a decision.
    2. Design: Inventing, developing, and analyzing possible courses of action.
    3. Choice: Selecting a course of action.
  • Strategic level managers require information that allows them to assess the environment and to project future events and conditions. 

    Tactical management requires information that is focused on relevant operational units. 

    Operational management needs information that is narrower in scope, more detailed, more accurate, and that comes largely from within the organization.

    Structure is the degree of repetition and routine in the decision. We can use the degree of structure inherent in each decision-making step to categorize the decisions as structured or unstructured.

    We define structured decisions as those for which all three decision phases are relatively routine or repetitive. Thus, we define unstructured decisions as those for which all three decision phases are not routine and/or repetitive.
  • After completing this module you will be able to:  
    • Describe the process known as Knowledge Management.
    • Explain what is meant by “groupware systems”.
    • List the two reasons that knowledge is often slow to enter such systems.
  • Gathering Knowledge with Groupware
  • Knowledge management is the process of capturing, storing, retrieving and distributing the knowledge of the individuals in an organization for use by others in the organization to improve the quality and/or efficiency of decision making across the firm. 

    The primary enabler of knowledge management efforts is the power of contemporary information technologies.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Effective knowledge management means that an organization must be able to connect the knowledge of one individual with other individuals in the firm who need the same knowledge. 

    Distribution dictates the use of electronic communications technology - namely groupware systems. Advanced database management systems and AI systems technologies for orderly storage and retrieval of the captured knowledge are also critical.

    All of the capabilities of groupware, as discussed earlier in this section, are pivotal to supporting knowledge management for organizations of virtually any size. Even the simplest components such as e-mail and document sharing are vital components. Add to these, the capability of Electronic Document Management systems and the information content of the electronically distributed messages vastly increases. 

    Indeed, many people consider the roots of knowledge management to be in the development of Lotus Notes, a widely used groupware system specifically designed to facilitate sharing of documents, e-mail, and group communication.

  • Creating A Knowledge Culture
  • A major challenge faced in developing effective knowledge management systems is a cultural issue. 

    Knowledge enters the knowledge management system only if individuals within an organization develop the necessary habit of entering information into the system.  

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • See Resource Section for Diagram.
  • There are two primary reasons that knowledge is often slow to enter such systems:
    • A reluctance to give up the power associated with being the keeper of some knowledge or expertise and
    • The failure to remember to enter information into the system when key problems have been resolved.

  • There are two primary reasons that knowledge is often slow to enter such systems:
    • A reluctance to give up the power associated with being the keeper of some knowledge or expertise and
    • The failure to remember to enter information into the system when key problems have been resolved.
  • The key points from this module are:
    • Knowledge management is the process of capturing, storing, retrieving and distributing the knowledge of the individuals in an organization for use by others in the organization to improve the quality and/or efficiency of decision making across the firm.
    • Distribution dictates the use of electronic communications technology - namely groupware systems. 
    • Advanced database management systems and AI systems technologies for orderly storage and retrieval of the captured knowledge are also critical.
    • At the heart of most knowledge management systems is a series of interconnected data management systems. 
    • Data warehousing technology enables the information needed for effective support of decision making to be integrated into a searchable warehouse of knowledge.
    • Much of the “knowledge” in systems is what is frequently referred to as “three-ring binder knowledge” consisting of items such as standard operating procedures manuals, employee resumes, troubleshooting guides, regulatory guidelines, and corporate codes.
    • There are two primary reasons that knowledge is often slow to enter such systems:
    • A reluctance to give up the power associated with being the keeper of some knowledge or expertise. 
    • The failure to remember to enter information into the system when key problems have been resolved.
